target_text: "We don’t achieve software quality without a process that implement and foster quality practices. It starts from the requirements elicitation and documentation to the testing. For example, we have review processes for the requirements, the code and the design. We have check lists and documented guidelines."

Role_Team.Subject: Geography
Role_Team.positionality: As a Product Owner pursuing a master’s in Geography, I approach spatial-economic questions through a pragmatic lens, prioritizing actionable insights for decision-making. My research interest in Economics steers me toward regional development, market accessibility, and place-based policy evaluation, often privileging quantitative, GIS-enabled evidence. I recognize my epistemological assumptions—positivist-leaning and optimization-oriented—which may undervalue lived experience and alternative ontologies. The way questions are framed and how users respond guide my sampling, coding, and model choices, potentially amplifying dominant stakeholder voices. By foregrounding reflexivity and triangulation, I seek to balance efficiency with equity and contextual nuance in interpreting results.

Role_Team.Subject: Statistics
Role_Team.positionality: As a software developer pursuing bachelor’s-level study in statistics, I bring computational problem-solving and data-driven habits to economic inquiry. My research goal is to produce reproducible, statistically rigorous analyses that inform practical economic decisions. I recognize that my cultural background, personal experiences, and a developer’s efficiency mindset can bias variable selection, model choice, and preference for quantifiable outcomes. To mitigate this, I triangulate methods, document assumptions, and invite critique. The question and user responses further shape my framing, operationalization, and interpretation, prompting reflexive checks that align my methods with the study’s context and stakeholders’ perspectives.

Role_Team.Subject: Anthropology
Role_Team.positionality: I am a software developer pursuing a master’s-level inquiry, bringing a computational mindset to anthropological questions. Guided by anthropology (QS) and research interests in economics (NSF), I aim to examine how digital infrastructures mediate economic behavior and inequality. My practice is shaped by ethical and societal assumptions—valuing fairness, privacy, open access, and sometimes technological solutionism—which I interrogate through reflexivity. The framing of the Question and the User’s Response directs my attention to certain categories and language, potentially privileging measurable patterns over lived meanings. Consequently, my interpretations may foreground systems, incentives, and data, while I strive to center participant voices and cultural context.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Researcher — PhD Candidate; QS: Computer Science (Software Engineering); NSF: Software Engineering/Empirical Methods; Bias: process-oriented, standards-centric

codebook.justification: Frames quality as process-dependent [We don’t achieve software quality without a process]. My SE lens (QS: CS/IS) foregrounds governance and quality management.
Claims end-to-end coverage [requirements elicitation and documentation to the testing]. My NSF SE interest privileges lifecycle traceability and V-model alignment.
Emphasizes peer control via [review processes]. As a PhD candidate, I read this as institutionalized V&V to reduce defect leakage.
Relies on compliance artifacts [check lists] and [documented guidelines]. My standards-centric bias may overvalue consistency over creative flexibility.

Role_init_codebook.role: Process-oriented Software Engineering Researcher, PhD Candidate (QS: Computer Science & Information Systems; NSF: Software & Hardware Foundations—Software Engineering; Bias: governance-first, pro-process, socio-technical lens)

codebook.justification: The phrasing [without a process] and [implement and foster quality practices] signal a governance-first quality stance. From a software QA perspective, process is framed as the primary assurance mechanism.
The span from [requirements elicitation and documentation] [to the testing] indicates full SDLC coverage. This encodes an end-to-end V&V orientation.
Emphasis on [review processes] [for the requirements, the code and the design] reflects a peer-review culture. It prioritizes collective oversight as a quality gate.
References to [check lists] and [documented guidelines] denote documentation-centric governance. This privileges traceability and compliance as quality proxies.

Role_init_codebook.role: Reflective Researcher (PhD; QS: Computer Science—Software Engineering; NSF: CISE–Software Systems; process-oriented bias)

codebook.justification: From a PhD-level SE lens, [software quality] is framed as unattainable [without a process] that [implement and foster quality practices]. This encodes a maturity-model assumption privileging formalized workflows.
I interpret scope as lifecycle-wide via [requirements elicitation and documentation to the testing]. This emphasizes continuity of assurance activities across phases.
Quality is socialized through [review processes] covering [the requirements, the code and the design]. My socio-technical bias reads this as institutionalized peer oversight.
Governance leans on artifacts like [check lists] and [documented guidelines]. I value traceability and standardization, so I foreground documentation rigor.

Agreed.definition: Quality is presented as contingent on an explicit process that implements and fosters practices, as stated in [We don’t achieve software quality without a process that implement and foster quality practices.].
Quality practices are described as spanning the full development lifecycle, per [It starts from the requirements elicitation and documentation to the testing.].
Formal review activities are positioned as quality gates over multiple artifacts, supported by [For example, we have review processes for the requirements, the code and the design.].

Disagreed.definition: Grounded in [We have check lists and documented guidelines.], this framing emphasizes the thoroughness/quality of documentation itself, diverging from interpretations that stress governance or compliance (focus difference).

Based on [It starts from the requirements elicitation and documentation to the testing.], this view elevates lifecycle scope to an assurance-centric narrative; the text states coverage but not the assurance abstraction explicitly (abstraction mismatch).

While supported by [For example, we have review processes for the requirements, the code and the design.], this label foregrounds socio-technical norms; the text emphasizes formal 'processes,' not cultural norms (viewpoint shift).

disagree_explain:
"Documentation rigor" is contested: roles read [We have check lists and documented guidelines.] as governance/compliance, not a claim about documentation quality itself. "End-to-End Assurance" over-abstracts: [It starts from the requirements elicitation and documentation to the testing.] signals lifecycle scope, not an assurance narrative. "Peer review norms" reframes [For example, we have review processes for the requirements, the code and the design.] as culture; roles see formal processes, not norms.
Click on the option under Disagreed Items on the left to start the discussion

Closing.definition: Retain because the text explicitly foregrounds documentation artifacts—checklists and documented guidelines—distinct from governance mentions of review processes. This separability enables annotators to capture documentation quality/standardization across the lifecycle, from requirements elicitation and documentation through testing, without conflating it with process oversight.

All roles agree to retain the code. The source text asserts end-to-end lifecycle coverage and enumerates practice-level controls (reviews, checklists, guidelines) but does not articulate an explicit assurance argument or structure. Retaining End-to-End Assurance flags this abstraction mismatch and improves annotation precision and consistency.

All roles agree to retain the disagree code because the passage emphasizes formal, documented review processes—checklists, guidelines, and defined procedures—rather than socio-cultural norms. Keeping this code flags viewpoint shifts when annotators might mislabel process-centric evidence as peer norms.
